reviewText: You'll Like My Mother is a great film. Patty Duke is marvelous in this gothic thriller. I was lucky enough to see it in the theatre.
Title: N/A

reviewText: YOU'LL LIKE MY MOTHER is actually a quote from an army draftee to his new bride, Francesa Kinsolving (Patty Duke). A premature death prevented him from having the opportunity to actually introduce them. So the expectant widow makes a journey to meet, in many ways, an unknown family. All of this you discover in the first few moments of the movie. What follows is one of the most chilling thrillers I've ever seen.Adding to the chill is the snowstorm greeting Francesa upon her arrival. It is evident from the moment the front door swings open that there is a discrepancy between reality and the promise of her late husband.Getting to the erie house in the snow with a third trimester  pregnancy was difficult enough. But this in no way compares to the challenges that must be faced to turn around and go back home. The movie keeps you on pins and needles. There are voices in the hallways, mysterious paintings, and shocking newspaper clippings. A serious lack of sanity on the part of anyone in the house heightens the deception and leaves little doubt that Francesa will ever get out alive.Thematic elements, two occasions of mild bad language and a violent climax earn the PG rating even though this appeared on television.
Title: N/A

reviewText: An intriguing and tautly directed thriller in which Patty Duke plays an expectant mother who journeys to the colds of Minnesota to the visit the family of her recently deceased Army husband.  What she discovers awaiting her arrival is quite different than she expected: a very twisted family indeed...A rather ingenious film which doesn't resort to any visual violence in order to keep a high level of terror and tension throughout, this film will also convince viewers that Richard Thomas could very successfully play against his stereotypical "John-Boy" character!  Shot entirely in Minnesota using the Congdon Mansion - which was constructed on the shore of Lake Superior in 1903 at a cost of 1.3 million dollars - this movie is characterised by creatively imaginitive cinematography.  Rosemary Murphy, a stage actress, made her transition to cinema extremely well: her performance is most effective.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I saw this movie as a teen and always remembered it as being great.  I just saw it again with my teenage son, and I loved it just as much.  The actress who plays the mother is wonderful at being cold hearted and creepy, and Patty Duke is spunky and cute in this movie.  It's also interesting to see Richard Thomas in this kind of role, when I always thought of him as the sweet John Boy Walton.This is a suspenseful movie with nice cinematography and great atmosphere.  The snow storm outside, large creepy mansion, low lighting, and shadows throughout make it a great scary movie to relish and enjoy.  It doesn't use violence to keep the interest and suspense, but focuses more on characters and atmosphere.  The story also unfolds with interesting revelations as it progresses, though the ending is somewhat abrupt.  I highly recommend this movie.  Now I just wish it would come out on DVD!  I've been waiting for years for a DVD release (and the tape is almost impossible to find).  We finally ended up watching it on the internet.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Richard Thomas comes out of Duluth's Congdon Mansion woodwork to pester a young Patty Duke in this 1972 pre-slasher thriller.  He's more like "The Shining"s Jack Nicholson than John-Boy Walton. "You'll Like My Mother" is a variation on the Captive In A Snow Storm theme that works very, very well. Not a good palliative for cabin fever, as it will induce more anxiety than it cures, but be brave! Turn down the lights, stoke up the fireplace, get some Hot Chocolate, and meet "Mother." Or be really, really brave and make it a Triple Feature: "You'll Like My Mother," "Misery," and Jack's "The Shining."  Reviewed by TundraVision
summary: Not the John-Boy we know and love
